body: Its controlled by the input buffer attribute. You can read more here: https://doc.akka.io/docs/akka/current/stream/stream-rate.html#internal-buffers-and-their-effect

Thanks! It'd be great to add information about this to JavaDoc.
Also, I've just tried to set the buffer size to 1 and I still have 2 more elements ahead of subscriber.

Also, I have to set these buffer settings globally. I need these settings for a single streaming service only. I don't want to use a separate actor system for that. I can't use another materialize because akka-grpc generated services accept actor systems only.

I think it isn't in the javadoc because it is not something specific the reactive stream integration but applies anywhere there is an async boundary, so it is more something that has a clear place to document in the API docs.

In general you won't get that much control with an async stream with Akka streams, that you will never get more than one element in flight, any operator can introduce explicit or implicit buffers if there is a benefit for their operation.

You can set the attribute for only a single operator or a stream subgraph to not have to specify it with the actorsystem global defaults.

> I think it isn't in the javadoc because it is not something specific the reactive stream integration but applies anywhere there is an async boundary, so it is more something that has a clear place to document in the API docs.
> 
> In general you won't get that much control with an async stream with Akka streams, that you will never get more than one element in flight, any operator can introduce explicit or implicit buffers if there is a benefit for their operation.
> 
> You can set the attribute for only a single operator or a stream subgraph to not have to specify it with the actorsystem global defaults.

I use `Source.fromPublisher` because I have to convert from another type of stream. And `Source.fromPublisher(pub).withAttributes(Attributes.inputBufferSize(1,1))` doesn't work for me.

Ah, I see, there is something funky with input buffer (or all attributes) for `Source.fromPublisher`, if I set the attributes on the whole graph, it correctly picks it up:

```
  Source.fromPublisher {
    Source.fromIterator(() => Iterator.from(1))
      .takeWhile(_ < 50)
      .map { i =>
        println(s"internal akka: $i")
        i
      }
      .runWith(Sink.asPublisher(false))
  }.map { i =>
    Thread.sleep(2000)
    println(s"akka: $i")
    i
  }.addAttributes(Attributes.inputBuffer(1, 1))
  .run()
```

rename.to: Source.fromPublisher does not pick up attributes correctly

body: Oh, wow. Thanks! `.withAttributes` right after `.fromPublisher `doesn't work, but after `.map` it works correctly.

_I am starting baby steps in akka-streams code base, please bare with my annoying (or dumb) questions_. I would like to pick this, but I need help to proceed

I am not able to understand, is it a feature or a bug? 

At the time of materialization, `GraphStageIsland#takePublisher` takes attributes from input side of the connection ( in other words downstream component attributes). 

I can pass source (or publisher)  attributes to downstream but is it good or not I don't know.

**Fix I am thinking about is**: 
```
override def takePublisher(slot: Int, publisher: Publisher[Any], publisherAttributes: Attributes): Unit = {
    val connection = conn(slot)
    val bufferSize = outOwnerAttributes.mandatoryAttribute[InputBuffer].max
    val boundary = new BatchingActorInputBoundary(bufferSize, shell, publisher, "publisher.in")
```

**PhaseIsland** trait looks like this

```
@DoNotInherit private[akka] trait PhaseIsland[M] {
  ...
  @InternalStableApi
  def takePublisher(slot: Int, publisher: Publisher[Any], publisherAttributes: Attributes = Attributes.none): Unit

  ...

}
```

Quite a deep end to get your feet wet in, just as a warning :) 

Isn't the `SourceModulePhase` used in this case since `PublisherSource` is a `SourceModule`? In that case the `takePublisher` override throws so that can't be the right place?

issue.body:
References #30935

Somewhat sketchy fix, but couldn't think of another way to cover both #30935 and #30076

This reverts the previous fix for #30076 (#30195) as that introduced a regression for "normal" cases.

body:
FTR, I think the original behavior was the intended one and should not have been changed. By definition an InputBuffer is in front of a stream component and not after. A Source has no stream component in front of it so changing the InputBuffer attribute should make no difference. That also explains the behavior of putting the attribute after `map` because it changes the `InputBuffer` going *into* map.

In general, expecting tight buffer control in akka-stream is usually an anti-pattern and should be used with much consideration. In particular, while you can add explicit asynchronous boundaries (including extra buffers), you cannot be sure that some boundaries like between `fromPublisher` and `map` are added implicitly (including extra buffers).

I agree that the change was questionable, so maybe we should indeed revert.

I think I've seen some reports of _other_ usage where tight buffer control has been expected that broke with this change. :/ 

For the record I think what made me accept trying to fix it was that with `Source.fromPublisher` there is a buffer "in front"/inside/between the stream and the publisher making it feel like weird ergonomics that what looks like it would control/set attributes for that operator in fact did not. It was not so much about the actual value of being able to tune that buffer.

> `Source.fromPublisher` there is a buffer "in front"/inside/between the stream and the publisher making it feel like weird ergonomics

Thinking about it again, I can see how you can see `Source.fromPublisher` as the encapsulation of the async boundary between an (external) publisher and an (akka-stream managed) stream, so it would indeed include the inputBuffer.

On the other hand, we actually do handle those publishers and the necessary async boundary transparently, so that the input boundary (and buffer) in question would only be part of the next element. So, tricky call, indeed...

issue.title: Revert #30195 - Source.fromPublisher does not pick up attributes fix

I think merging this should re-open #30076 

This reverts commit a887c63f8a52403a1f088b630f02b235ac867bd0.
